H0.text: Chromosomes are found in greater numbers in muscle cells than in most other types of cells, enabling the rapid conversion of energy from food molecules into a usable form.

H1.text: Mitochondria are present in greater numbers in muscle cells than most other types of cells because muscle cells need to quickly convert energy from food molecules into a usable form.

H2.text: Nuclei are present in greater numbers in muscle cells than most other types of cells, enabling the rapid conversion of energy from food molecules into a usable form.

H3.text: Vacuoles are present in greater numbers in muscle cells than in most other cell types because muscle cells need to quickly convert energy from food molecules into a usable form.

A4.text: Skeletal muscle fibers are the only muscle cells that are multinucleated with the nuclei usually referred to as myonuclei.

A5.text: This occurs during myogenesis with the fusion of myoblasts, each contributing a nucleus to the newly formed muscle cell or myotube.
